                        <gmd:MD_Identifier>
                            <gmd:authority>

                            </gmd:code>
                        </gmd:MD_Identifier>
                    </gmd:identifier>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>Heidi Swanson</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>Dehcho First Nations</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>University of Waterloo</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>Mercury is a global contaminant that accumulates in organisms, including humans, and can result in many health problems. Eating fish is the primary route by which humans are exposed to mercury, and mercury levels tend to be high in northern regions due to global atmospheric circulation patterns and atmospheric deposition of mercury. Our aim is to understand what the key drivers of fish mercury concentrations are in traditional fishing lakes in the Dehcho region, and how/if these drivers vary predictably among lakes.  Furthermore, the water quality, sediment quality, fish tissue and fish health results have informed consumption guidelines of the fish in the waterbodies being studied, as fish are a valuable traditional food resource to First Nations.  

During a study conducted over the last three years funded by CIMP (#00154), Northern Contaminants Program, Health Canada, and NSERC, we found that some Dehcho lakes have high mercury concentrations in top predator food fish species, such as Northern Pike (exceed Health Canada consumption guidelines), whereas other lakes have relatively low mercury concentrations in these species.  Our results found that among-lake variability in fish mercury concentrations are not fully explained by any of the variety of variables we investigated, including fish growth rates, fish trophic position, fish age, and fish size. We also found an interesting decoupling between mercury concentrations in water and mercury concentrations in fish, and that lakes with high fish mercury concentrations do not necessarily have high rates of mercury biomagnification through the food web.  The water quality and fish data also establish reference conditions for the area relative to future development and a changing climate.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

            </gmd:resourceConstraints>
            
            
            <gmd:language>
                <gco:CharacterString>eng</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:language>

                <gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>inlandWaters</gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>
            </gmd:topicCategory>

                            </gmd:westBoundLongitude>

                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>

                            </gmd:southBoundLatitude>

                                <gco:Decimal>63.188972</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                        </gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                    </gmd:geographicElement>
                    <gmd:temporalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                            <gmd:extent>
                                <gml:TimePeriod gml:id="TimePeriod">
                                    <gml:description>seconds</gml:description>

                                    <gml:endPosition>2019-09-07T00:00:00+00:00</gml:endPosition>
                                </gml:TimePeriod>

                        </gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                    </gmd:temporalElement>
                    <gmd:verticalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_VerticalExtent>

        </gmd:MD_DataIdentification>
    </gmd:identificationInfo>

name: 10-25976-j1fz-z275
notes:
Mercury is a global contaminant that accumulates in organisms, including humans, and can result in many health problems. Eating fish is the primary route by which humans are exposed to mercury, and mercury levels tend to be high in northern regions due to global atmospheric circulation patterns and atmospheric deposition of mercury. Our aim is to understand what the key drivers of fish mercury concentrations are in traditional fishing lakes in the Dehcho region, and how/if these drivers vary predictably among lakes.  Furthermore, the water quality, sediment quality, fish tissue and fish health results have informed consumption guidelines of the fish in the waterbodies being studied, as fish are a valuable traditional food resource to First Nations.  

During a study conducted over the last three years funded by CIMP (#00154), Northern Contaminants Program, Health Canada, and NSERC, we found that some Dehcho lakes have high mercury concentrations in top predator food fish species, such as Northern Pike (exceed Health Canada consumption guidelines), whereas other lakes have relatively low mercury concentrations in these species.  Our results found that among-lake variability in fish mercury concentrations are not fully explained by any of the variety of variables we investigated, including fish growth rates, fish trophic position, fish age, and fish size. We also found an interesting decoupling between mercury concentrations in water and mercury concentrations in fish, and that lakes with high fish mercury concentrations do not necessarily have high rates of mercury biomagnification through the food web.  The water quality and fish data also establish reference conditions for the area relative to future development and a changing climate.

notes_translated.en:
Mercury is a global contaminant that accumulates in organisms, including humans, and can result in many health problems. Eating fish is the primary route by which humans are exposed to mercury, and mercury levels tend to be high in northern regions due to global atmospheric circulation patterns and atmospheric deposition of mercury. Our aim is to understand what the key drivers of fish mercury concentrations are in traditional fishing lakes in the Dehcho region, and how/if these drivers vary predictably among lakes.  Furthermore, the water quality, sediment quality, fish tissue and fish health results have informed consumption guidelines of the fish in the waterbodies being studied, as fish are a valuable traditional food resource to First Nations.  

During a study conducted over the last three years funded by CIMP (#00154), Northern Contaminants Program, Health Canada, and NSERC, we found that some Dehcho lakes have high mercury concentrations in top predator food fish species, such as Northern Pike (exceed Health Canada consumption guidelines), whereas other lakes have relatively low mercury concentrations in these species.  Our results found that among-lake variability in fish mercury concentrations are not fully explained by any of the variety of variables we investigated, including fish growth rates, fish trophic position, fish age, and fish size. We also found an interesting decoupling between mercury concentrations in water and mercury concentrations in fish, and that lakes with high fish mercury concentrations do not necessarily have high rates of mercury biomagnification through the food web.  The water quality and fish data also establish reference conditions for the area relative to future development and a changing climate.
notes_translated.fr:
Le mercure est un contaminant mondial qui s'accumule dans les organismes, y compris les humains, et peut entraîner de nombreux problèmes de santé. La consommation de poisson est la principale voie d'exposition des humains au mercure, et les niveaux de mercure ont tendance à être élevés dans les régions nordiques en raison des schémas de circulation atmosphérique mondiale et des dépôts atmosphériques de mercure. Notre objectif est de comprendre quels sont les principaux facteurs des concentrations de mercure dans les poissons dans les lacs de pêche traditionnels de la région du Dehcho, et comment et si ces facteurs varient de manière prévisible d'un lac à l'autre. En outre, les résultats relatifs à la qualité de l'eau, à la qualité des sédiments, aux tissus des poissons et à la santé des poissons ont éclairé les recommandations relatives à la consommation du poisson dans les plans d'eau étudiés, car le poisson constitue une ressource alimentaire traditionnelle précieuse pour les Premières nations. 

Au cours d'une étude menée au cours des trois dernières années et financée par le CIMP (#00154), le Northern Contaminants Program, Santé Canada et le CRSNG, nous avons découvert que certains lacs du Dehcho présentaient des concentrations élevées de mercure dans les principales espèces de poissons destinées à l'alimentation, comme le grand brochet (dépassant les recommandations de consommation de Santé Canada), tandis que d'autres lacs présentaient des concentrations de mercure relativement faibles chez ces espèces. Nos résultats ont révélé que la variabilité des concentrations de mercure dans les poissons d'un lac à l'autre n'est entièrement expliquée par aucune des diverses variables que nous avons étudiées, notamment les taux de croissance des poissons, leur position trophique, leur âge et leur taille. Nous avons également constaté un découplage intéressant entre les concentrations de mercure dans l'eau et les concentrations de mercure dans les poissons, et nous avons constaté que les lacs présentant de fortes concentrations de mercure dans les poissons ne présentent pas nécessairement des taux élevés de bioamplification du mercure dans le réseau trophique. Les données sur la qualité de l'eau et les poissons établissent également des conditions de référence pour la zone en ce qui concerne le développement futur et le changement climatique.

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.
